title: Epsom Downs Walks

images.title: Sunil060902 / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0)
images.caption: Tattenham Corner public house, opposite Epsom Downs race course and near Tattenham Corner station. The pub is located close to the start and end point of the walk.

images.title: Bill Boaden / Epsom Downs
images.caption: View of the downs in the summer of 2009. A very pleasant place to walk, and the surrounding race course is not all intrusive or restrictive.

images.title: Hugh Craddock / Finishing straight, Epsom Downs
images.caption: Finishing straight, Epsom Downs Looking down the finishing straight from the Old London Road crossing of the racecourse, just off Tattenham Corner Road (B290). The crossing is closed on racedays, and to vehicles at night.

images.title: Hywel Williams / Epsom Racecourse Stadium
images.caption: Epsom Racecourse Stadium. Taken from near the finishing line, this is the modern Queen's Stand. The futuristic looking pavilion building was used as a filming location for the James Bond film Goldeneye.

images.title: Walton Road: view across Six Mile Hill by Hugh Craddock, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Walton Road, view across Six Mile Hill

images.title: Hugh Craddock / Walton Road at the bottom of Six Mile Hill
images.caption: Walton Road descends to the bottom of Six Mile Hill, approaching the all-weather track, the sand track (for hack riders' use) and bridleway 66, and the end-on junction with Ebbisham Lane.

images.title: Bridleway near Round Wood by Hugh Craddock, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridleway near Round Wood

description: This circular walk takes you around Epsom Downs racecourse in Surrey. The downs consist of attractive chalk downland, grassland and woodland. You'll also enjoy wonderful views across the famous racecourse which hosts the Epsom Derby and the Oaks. You can start your walk from the Tattenham Corner car park at the northern end of the downs. Tattenham Corner train station is also very close to the start of the walk so you can easily visit by public transport. The footpath then passes through the course, heading across Walton Downs towards Walton on the Hill. The route then skirts the edge of Banstead Heath before returning to the car park via Tadworth Farm. The area is great for wildlife spotting. Look out for Skylarks and various butterflies including the rare Chalk Hill Blue. The walk can be extended by further exploring Banstead Heath which is criss crossed with miles of footpaths. There's lots of good options if you'd like to extend your walking in the area. A couple of miles to the north west you'll find Epsom Common and Ashtead Common National Nature Reserve. Both of these large open spaces have nice walking trails to follow. The Thames Down Link passes through Ashtead Park just to the west of the downs. National Cycle Network Route 22 crosses part of the downs so you can bring your bike too. You can explore large sections of the racecourse using the google street view link below.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Tattenham Corner pub is located at the start/end of the route and a good place for some post walk refreshments. They do good food and have a large garden area with views of Epsom Downs. It's a nice place to relax on warmer days. You can find it at a postcode of KT18 5NY.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The downs are a great place for a dog walk and you'll probably see plenty of other owners with their pets on your visit. You are advised to please keep them on leads in the morning when the horses exercise on the downs.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The circular Tadworth Walk starts from the train station in the nearby town. It visits the Downs and Banstead Heath to the south.

display_address: Old London Road, Epsom, Epsom and Ewell, Surrey, England, KT18 5UL, United Kingdom
